content.text: Identify the quantity that is the same for all the masses
Tick **one** box
The largest mass is \(2.5 \mathrm{kg}\)
State the number of grams in \(2.5 \mathrm{kg}\)
The three largest masses are \(2.5 \mathrm{kg}, 1.0 \mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.5 \mathrm{kg}\)
Calculate the combined **weight** of these three masses. Include the unit
Fig. 1.1 shows a set of masses made from the same material
A student describes part of the journey
The bus accelerates from rest at a constant rate for 10s. It reaches a maximum speed of \(10\mathrm{m / s}\)
The bus maintains a constant speed of \(10\mathrm{m / s}\) for 60s
The bus then decelerates at a constant rate for 15s, until it stops
On Fig. 2.2, draw the speed-time graph for this part of the journey made by the bus
On another part of the journey, the average speed of the bus is \(7.5 \text{m / s}\)
Calculate the distance the bus travels in 150s
Fig. 2.1 shows students getting onto a school bus
State the name of the force acting vertically downwards
The vertical force that acts upwards is 4.0N
State the value of the force acting vertically downwards
The load is pulled downwards and then released. The load moves up and down
Fig. 3.2 represents the vertical forces acting on the load at some time after it is released
Calculate the resultant force on the load and state its direction
resultant force =   .........  N
State the principle of conservation of energy
Eventually the load stops moving up and down
Describe and explain why the load stops moving. Use your ideas about conservation of energy
A load is attached to a spring, as shown in Fig. 3.1. Two arrows indicate the vertical forces acting on the load. The spring and the load are stationary
The truck is stationary. Identify the quantities that determine the work done as it lifts the load
Tick the box next to each correct quantity
Draw a ring around the unit for work done from the list
joule newton pascal watt
Identify the quantities that determine the power of the truck
Tick the box next to each correct quantity
The truck has a pivot near the front wheel. Fig. 4.2 represents the pivot and the vertical forces acting on the truck
The truck is in equilibrium
Calculate the load
On Fig. 4.3, draw a cross to indicate the centre of mass of the pile of bricks
The truck can tilt the pile of bricks backwards, as shown in Fig. 4.4
Explain how tilting the pile of bricks backwards makes the truck more stable
Fig. 4.3 shows another truck lifting a pile of identical bricks
Fig. 4.1 shows a truck lifting a heavy load
The solar farm converts energy from a source into a different, useful form of energy
State the energy source and the useful form of energy
source
useful form of energy
State two advantages of a solar farm
State one disadvantage of a solar farm
Solar farms have advantages and disadvantages
Suggest why it is useful that the panels can tilt and rotate
Fig. 5.1 shows part of a solar farm. The solar panels tilt and rotate
On Fig. 6.1, draw two arrows to show how thermal energy moves throughout the oven by convection
Explain how thermal energy moves throughout the oven by convection. Use your ideas about density and expansion
Use a word from the box to complete the sentence
Thermal energy travels at the speed of light by ............................................
Fig. 6.1 shows a cross-section of the inside of an electric oven
The heater is switched on
The oven is in a kitchen that is fitted with a smoke detector
Warm, moving air can carry smoke particles
Suggest the best position for the smoke detector in the kitchen
Light and sound both travel as waves
Draw a line from each statement to the correct term that describes it. One has been done for you
Fig. 8.1 shows an incomplete diagram of the electromagnetic spectrum
higher frequency longer wavelength
Complete Fig. 8.1 with the names of the missing types of radiation in the correct boxes.
State one use for ultraviolet radiation
State the term used to describe each electrical circuit. Write the term under each circuit.
State two disadvantages of the circuit in Fig. 9.2
Redraw the circuit in Fig. 9.1 with switches that will turn lamps X and Y on and off independently of each other
Fig. 9.3 shows another circuit
The lamps can be turned on and off using two different switches \(\mathsf{S}_1\) and \(\mathsf{S}_2\)
Complete the table stating when the lamps are on or off. The first one has been done for you
Fig. 9.1 and Fig. 9.2 each show an electrical circuit. Each circuit has two lamps connected to an electrical supply
Fig. 9.1 Fig. 9.2
Identify the pieces of equipment that are electrical conductors and those that are electrical insulators. Draw a line from each piece of equipment to the correct box

table.html:
aluminium clamp and stand
plastic stirrup
iron nail
cotton thread

content.text: State and explain how the polythene strip can be given a negative charge
Describe how the apparatus in Fig. 10.1 could be used to demonstrate that the polythene strip has a negative charge
Fig. 10.1 shows the apparatus for an experiment on electrostatics
The statements describe the action of a relay. They are not in the correct order
P Current in the coil creates an electromagnet
Q Secondary circuit is completed
R Armature pivots, closing the contacts
S Part C attracts the armature
T The switch in the primary circuit is closed
Place the statements in the correct order. One has been done for you
Fig. 11.1 includes the part labelled C, which is made from a metal
State the name of the metal and explain why this metal is used in the electromagnet
metal
explanation
Fig. 11.1 shows a relay
Complete the table to describe the nucleus of astatine-210
The count rate of a sample of astatine-210 is measured over 24 hours
On Fig. 12.1, sketch a line to show how the count rate changes over the 24 hours
The mass of a sample of astatine-210 is \(0.500 \text{kg}\)
Calculate how long it takes for \(0.375 \text{kg}\) of the sample to decay
decay time =   .........  hours
Astatine-210 has a half-life of 8 hours
Astatine-210 is a radioactive material. The nucleus of astatine can be represented by the symbol shown
